description: From Middle English intrusioun, from Old French intrusion, from Medieval Latin intrūsiō, from intrūdō, from Latin in- + trūdō.

entries.meaning: The forcible inclusion or entry of an external group or individual; the act of intruding.
examples: He viewed sales calls as an unwelcome intrusion.

entries.meaning: (geology) Magma forced into other rock formations; the rock formed when such magma solidifies.
A structure that lies within a historic district but is nonhistoric and irrelevant to the district.
(phonology) The insertion of a phoneme into the pronunciation of a word despite its absence from the spelling. (e.g. intrusive r)
